wikipedia_page.main:
John Linnett (1859 – 16 May 1902) was a member of the Queensland Legislative Assembly.He was born at Essex, England, the son of William Linnett and his wife Rachel (née Cook). On arrival in Queensland, he trained as a butcher in Rockhampton from 1874 and remained in the industry all his life.
On 25 August 1887, he married Ellen Conner in Rockhampton. He died there in May 1902 and his funeral proceeded from his former residence to the North Rockhampton Cemetery.

response: *John Linnett (1859–1902), member of the Queensland Legislative Assembly

link_mentions.page: Members of the Queensland Legislative Assembly, 1899–1902
response: : James Stewart, the Labour member for North Rockhampton, became a Senator for Queensland and resigned his Assembly seat on 5 June 1901. Labour candidate Henry Turner won the resulting by-election on 22 June 1901 with a majority of one vote. This result was set aside upon petition on 17 October 1901 and Independent candidate John Linnett was declared elected without a further by-election.

Upon the resignation of James Stewart to stand for a senate seat in the 1901 federal election,1901 Senate – Psephos. Retrieved 29 March. Turner, representing the Labour Party, contested the subsequent by-election in June of that year and defeated the Ministerial candidate, John Linnett. The election outcome was successfully challenged in the courts by Linnett and he was declared duly elected.
